image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant nicknamed "Pirola" has been detected in Australia after sparking a sped-up vaccination program in the United Kingdom.

title.children: The 'highly mutated' COVID variant BA.2.86 — known as Pirola — has landed in Australia

title.children: Queensland braces for high temperatures, threat of bushfires

image.altText: a young woman sick with a cold sitting on a bed blowing her nose with a tissue

props.synopsis: Queensland's chief health officer says the public should be "alert but not alarmed", after a surge in Group A Streptococcus infections. Here's how to stay safe.

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addresses a high level Security Council meeting.

image.altText: Von der Leyen can be seen in focus in between soldiers

props.synopsis: A former musician who was once forced to go into hiding from terrorists, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's path to power has been an incredible journey.

title.children: How a young girl destined to become a 'housewife at the side of a powerful man' instead grew up to lead Europe through crisis

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

image.altText: A woman in stage holding a pillow, eye mask and holding a cocktail

props.synopsis: Emma-June Curik was initially very guarded about sharing her disability but has since turned her diagnosis journey into a cabaret performance.

title.children: Musicians with disabilities say the music scene is getting better for everyone. Here's why

image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

title.children: El Niño makes a scorching summer more likely. These cities might feel it most

image.altText: Barnaby Joyce speaks at a press conference, where journalists hold microphones. Other politicians stand behind him.

props.synopsis: An unlikely coalition of Australian parliamentarians converges on Washington to lobby US decision-makers to drop the legal pursuit of Julian Assange and grant his freedom by Christmas.

title.children: 'We came here to get a resolution': Australian MPs lobby Washington for Assange's freedom

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A respected religious leader from north-east Arnhem Land wants the No campaign to retract his image from its campaign material and publicly announce that it has done so.

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material

image.altText: George RR Martin

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Game of Thrones author George RR Martin sues OpenAI for 'systematic theft', Australia urges US to let Julian Assange walk free. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Authorities in New South Wales say it will take several days to bring fires under control as a cool change moves through the state. The north-western region of the state is under a total fire bin today, with hot and windy conditions forecast. More than 60 fires are still burning following above-average September heat during the first half of the week. Meanwhile, fire crews in Queensland are on stand-by for worsening conditions today, with parts of the coast expecting record temperatures of 40C. There are total fire bans for the Barcoo shire in the state's south-west. Queensland firefighters have been battling multiple bushfires since the weekend, with a helicopter pilot having a lucky escape after crashing into a dam while fighting a fire.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fire authorities in Queensland and NSW still on high alert

children.content: (Supplied: QFES)
Authorities in New South Wales say it will take several days to bring fires under control as a cool change moves through the state.
The north-western region of the state is under a total fire bin today, with hot and windy conditions forecast.
More than 60 fires are still burning following above-average September heat during the first half of the week.
Meanwhile, fire crews in Queensland are on stand-by for worsening conditions today, with parts of the coast expecting record temperatures of 40C.
There are total fire bans for the Barcoo shire in the state's south-west.
Queensland firefighters have been battling multiple bushfires since the weekend, with a helicopter pilot having a lucky escape after crashing into a dam while fighting a fire.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Elon Musk's brain-chip startup Neuralink says it will begin recruiting for the first human trial of its brain implant for paralysis patients. The company received approval from an independent review board in May, though it's not known how many patients have ultimately been approved for the trial. The study will use a robot to surgically place a brain-computer interface implant in a region of the brain that controls the intention to move. Neuralink says the the goal is to allow those with paralysis to control a computer cursor or keyboard using their thoughts alone. Musk has grand ambitions for the company, saying it will facilitate speedy surgical insertions of its chip devices to treat conditions like obesity, autism, depression and schizophrenia. Here's Ryan Merkley from the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine explaining how the implant would work and the ethical concerns it raises:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Elon Musk's Neuralink to start human trial of brain implant

children.content: Elon Musk's brain-chip startup Neuralink says it will begin recruiting for the first human trial of its brain implant for paralysis patients.
The company received approval from an independent review board in May, though it's not known how many patients have ultimately been approved for the trial.
The study will use a robot to surgically place a brain-computer interface implant in a region of the brain that controls the intention to move.
Neuralink says the the goal is to allow those with paralysis to control a computer cursor or keyboard using their thoughts alone.
Musk has grand ambitions for the company, saying it will facilitate speedy surgical insertions of its chip devices to treat conditions like obesity, autism, depression and schizophrenia.
Here's Ryan Merkley from the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine explaining how the implant would work and the ethical concerns it raises:

mediaThumbnail.caption: One group of doctors says the lab tests on animals for Neuralink raise serious safety and ethical concerns.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A UK ban on new petrol and diesel cars has been pushed back to 2035 from 2030. The five-year delay comes as UK Prime Minister, Rishi Sunak, announces the watering down of Britain's climate targets. He says the move is necessary to maintain the consent of the British people in the switch to net zero emissions. Mr Sunak says his government remains committed to hitting this legally-binding target by 2050. Targets around the phased introduction of heat pumps to replace gas boilers in homes have also been eased.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UK delays petrol car ban as it pushes back net zero targets

children.content: Rishi Sunak changes Britain's climate targets.
(Reuters: Justin Tallis)
A UK ban on new petrol and diesel cars has been pushed back to 2035 from 2030.
The five-year delay comes as UK Prime Minister, Rishi Sunak, announces the watering down of Britain's climate targets.
He says the move is necessary to maintain the consent of the British people in the switch to net zero emissions.
Mr Sunak says his government remains committed to hitting this legally-binding target by 2050.
Targets around the phased introduction of heat pumps to replace gas boilers in homes have also been eased.

image.altText: A small brown Malleefowl chick ina mans hands

props.synopsis: The chicken-sized, chick-abandoning birds have one thing in common with the tiny bush town trying to save them.

title.children: Inside the fight to save a little town and its vulnerable bird population

image.altText: Jerome Powell stands at a podium behind a wall of American flags.

props.synopsis: A fall on Wall Street is likely to send Australian stocks lower after the US Federal Reserve projects another rate hike by year end. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: US Fed holds interest rates steady but projects one more rate rise in 2023, ASX to fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US central bank held interest rates steady as expected at the end of a two-day policy meeting, but the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee said "inflation remains elevated" and Fed chair Jerome Powell said the Fed's job is to lower it. "We are committed to achieving and sustaining sufficiently restrictive policy to bring inflation down to 2 per cent over time," Powell said at a press conference, adding that reducing inflation is likely to require a period of below trend growth. The Fed's announcement was accompanied by its Summary Economic Projections (SEP) and dot plot, which sees an additional 25 basis point rate hike this year, peaking in the 5.5 to 5.75 per cent range. Fed officials now see the personal consumption expenditures price index at 3.3 per cent at year end, up from June's forecast of 3.2 per cent, and its overnight lending rate to be 5.1 per cent at the end of 2024, about 50 basis points higher than futures have projected. "The Fed is trying to send as hawkish a signal as it possibly can. It's just a question of whether the markets will listen to them without taking them with a grain of salt," said Gennadiy Goldberg, head of US interest rate strategy at TD Securities in New York. "They're talking about higher rates for longer, but it's really the economy that matters. And if the economy starts to soften, I don't think these dot plot projections will actually hold up."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US Fed sees 25 bp hike this year, 50 bp cuts in 2024

children.content: The US central bank held interest rates steady as expected at the end of a two-day policy meeting, but the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee said "inflation remains elevated" and Fed chair Jerome Powell said the Fed's job is to lower it.

"We are committed to achieving and sustaining sufficiently restrictive policy to bring inflation down to 2 per cent over time," Powell said at a press conference, adding that reducing inflation is likely to require a period of below trend growth.
The Fed's announcement was accompanied by its Summary Economic Projections (SEP) and dot plot, which sees
an additional 25 basis point rate hike this year, peaking in the 5.5 to 5.75 per cent range
Fed officials now see the personal consumption expenditures price index at 3.3 per cent at year end, up from June's forecast of 3.2 per cent, and
its overnight lending rate to be 5.1 per cent at the end of 2024
, about 50 basis points higher than futures have projected.

"The Fed is trying to send as hawkish a signal as it possibly can. It's just a question of whether the markets will listen to them without taking them with a grain of salt," said Gennadiy Goldberg, head of US interest rate strategy at TD Securities in New York.
"They're talking about higher rates for longer, but it's really the economy that matters. And if the economy starts to soften, I don't think these dot plot projections will actually hold up."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to today's markets live blog, where we'll bring you the latest price action and news on the ASX and beyond. A tumble on Wall Street overnight set the tone for local market action today. The Dow Jones index dropped 0.2 per cent, the S & P 500 lost 0.9 per cent and the Nasdaq Composite was down 1.5 per cent. ASX futures were down 20 points or 0.2 per cent to 7,151 at 7:30am AEST. At the same time, the Australian dollar was flat at 64.46 US cents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to follow Wall Street lower

children.content: Good morning and welcome to today's markets live blog, where we'll bring you the latest price action and news on the ASX and beyond.
A tumble on Wall Street overnight set the tone for local market action today.
The Dow Jones index dropped 0.2 per cent, the S
P 500 lost 0.9 per cent and the Nasdaq Composite was down 1.5 per cent.
ASX futures were down 20 points or 0.2 per cent to 7,151 at 7:30am AEST.
At the same time, the Australian dollar was flat at 64.46 US cents.

image.altText: The silhouette of a firefighter is seen in front of a large bushfire burning high into trees.

props.synopsis: Catastrophic fire danger warnings have been issued in parts of Australia already as it enters a hotter and drier than average climate pattern. If the fire season has taken you by surprise, here's a reminder of how the warning system works.

image.altText: people sitting on the ground, digging for bones
